Authors: Ting Cao, jiarui Yu , Haisheng Yuan
Title:
A phylogenetic overview of the Hydnaceae (Cantharellales,
Basidiomycota) with new taxa from China
Abstract:
The family Hydnaceae (Cantharellales, Basidiomycota) is a
group of fungi found worldwide which exhibit stichic nuclear division.
The group is highly diverse in morphology, ecology, and phylogeny, and
includes some edible mushrooms which are popular all over the world.
Traditionally, Hydnaceae together with Cantharellaceae, Clavulinaceae
and Sistotremataceae are parallel families in the Cantharellales. The
four genera were combined and redefined as “Hydnaceae”, however, a
comprehensive phylogeny based on mutiple-marker dataset for the entire
Hydnaceae sensu stricto is still lacking and the delimitation is also
unclear. We inferred Maximum Likelihood and Bayesian phylogenies for the
family Hydnaceae from the data of five DNA regions: the large subunit of
nuclear ribosomal RNA gene (nLSU), the mitochondrial small subunit rDNA
gene (mtSSU), the internal transcribed spacer regions (ITS), the second
largest subunit of RNA polymerase II (RPB2) and the translation
elongation factor 1-alpha gene (TEF1). We also produced three more
phylogenetic trees for Cantharellus based on nLSU, mtSSU, 5.8S, RPB2 and
TEF1, Craterellus and Hydnum based on the combined nLSU and ITS. The
status of Hydnaceae in the order Cantharellales has been reproduced, and
17 genera phylogenetically confirmed in Hydnaceae by this study. 29 new
taxa or synonyms are described, revealed, proposed, or reported,
including 8 new subgenera (Cantharellus subgenus Magnus, Craterellus
subgenus Imperforati, subg. Longibasidiosi, subg. Tubati, subg. Ovoidei,
subg. Lamelles, subg. Cariosi and Hydnum subgenus Minoablbum); 17 new
species (Ca. laevihymeninus, Ca. magnus, Ca. subminor, Cr. badiogriseus,
Cr. croceialbus, Cr. macrosporus, Cr. squamatus, H. flabellatum, H.
flavidocanum, H. longibasidium, H. pallidecroceum, H. pallidomarginatum,
H. parvialbum, H. sphaericum, H. tangerinum, H. tenuistipitum and H.
ventricosum); two synonyms (Ca. anzutake and Ca. tuberculosporus as Ca.
yunnanensis) and two newly recorded species (H. albomagnum and H.
minum). The distinguishing characters of the new species and subgenera
as well as their allied taxa are discussed in the notes which follow
them. The delimitation and diversity in morphology, ecology, and
phylogeny of Hydnaceae is discussed. Notes of 17 genera which are
phylogenetically accepted in Hydnaceae by this study and a key to the
genera in Hydnaceae are provided.
